title: 3 DIY Ways to Transfer Photos & Drawings to Wood

steps.title: Cut the printed photo to the same size as the wood.
steps.content: Cut the printed photo to the same size as the wood. Use a pair of scissors to cut the photo to size. Make sure the main focus of the picture is in the middle of the piece of wood when you’re done cutting it down. [1] X Research source Make sure the photo is flipped horizontally if there are any words on it so they don’t transfer backwards. Wood slices with bark can be purchased at your local arts and crafts store, but any smooth, flat piece of wood will work.

steps.title: Paint a thin layer of Mod Podge on the wood’s surface.
steps.content: Paint a thin layer of Mod Podge on the wood’s surface. [2] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 9 September 2020. Mod Podge is an adhesive and transfer agent used in many crafts. Pour a coin-sized amount onto the wood’s surface and spread it evenly with a foam brush. Make sure there are no bubbles or large pools of the Mod Podge on the wood. Smooth out all of the liquid and remove any excess with the edge of the foam brush. [3] X Research source You can also use any photo transfer medium in place of the Mod Podge.

steps.title: Press the photo onto the wood.
steps.content: Press the photo onto the wood. [4] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 9 September 2020. Set the photo on top of the wood face-down so it lays flat on the Mod Podge. Use the side of your fist to rub the photo onto the wood to remove any air bubbles and ensure the photo completely transfers. [5] X Research source Use a rubber roller, or brayer, to help flatten the picture.

steps.title: Let the photo set for 24 hours.
steps.content: Let the photo set for 24 hours. Leave the photo in a cool, dry place so it can fully transfer onto the wood’s surface. Don’t lift the photo off the piece of wood at all. [6] X Research source Keep the wood on a counter or tabletop out of reach of pets so it can dry undisturbed.

steps.title: Wet a cloth and gently rub the back of the paper.
steps.content: Wet a cloth and gently rub the back of the paper. Run a washcloth under warm water and wring it out. Lay the rag on top of the paper and press it down to get the picture wet. Use gentle back and forth motions to rub the paper away from the photo. The paper should easily tear away while the picture stays on the wood. [7] X Research source You can let the picture dry and then rub it again with another wet cloth to pull up any remaining residue.

steps.title: Seal the photo with a matte finish.
steps.content: Seal the photo with a matte finish. Paint a thin layer on the wood’s surface to protect the picture. [8] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 9 September 2020. Let the first layer dry before painting the second layer in the opposite direction. Once it’s dry, your photo is complete! [9] X Research source Purchase a matte finish from your local arts and crafts store. Remember to wash off your paint brush when you finish!

steps.title: Put a printed photo face-down on the piece of wood.
steps.content: Put a printed photo face-down on the piece of wood. Print the picture on regular paper with a laser or HP printer. Make sure the photo is the same size as the piece of wood you’re using. [10] X Research source If the photo has words on it, flip it horizontally on your computer so the words read the right way once it’s transferred.

steps.title: Wet a cotton ball with nail polish remover and rub the back of the picture.
steps.content: Wet a cotton ball with nail polish remover and rub the back of the picture. Dip the cotton ball in the nail polish and rub it back and forth across the picture. The paper will become slightly transparent so you can see the picture on the other side. Coat the entire picture with the remover. [11] X Research source Use makeup cleaning pads instead of cotton balls to cover more surface area.

steps.title: Press the photo onto the wood with the back of a spoon.
steps.content: Press the photo onto the wood with the back of a spoon. As soon as you’ve applied the nail polish remover, put firm pressure on the back of the spoon to transfer the photo onto the wood’s surface. Move back and forth across the back of the photo so it lays down evenly. [12] X Research source Alternatively, use a brayer to roll the photo smooth.

steps.title: Peel the paper off of the piece of wood slowly.
steps.content: Peel the paper off of the piece of wood slowly. Pinch the corner of the paper between your fingers and peel it back from the wood. The photo should have completely transferred onto its surface. [13] X Research source If the paper starts to rip, try pulling it from a different corner instead.

steps.title: Glue a piece of wax paper to a sheet of printer paper.
steps.content: Glue a piece of wax paper to a sheet of printer paper. Use a glue stick to attach the wax paper to a regular sheet of printer paper. Make sure the glossy side of the wax paper is facing up. This will make it easier for the wax paper to go through the printer without ripping or jamming. [14] X Research source Don’t leave any lumps of glue between the paper since this could jam the printer.

steps.title: Print the picture onto the wax paper.
steps.content: Print the picture onto the wax paper. [15] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 9 September 2020. Feed the paper into the printer so the photo prints on the glossy side of the wax paper. Make sure the photo prints out to the same size as your piece of wood. [16] X Research source You can use either a laser or inkjet printer on the wax paper. Mark a regular piece of paper in your printer and make a test print. Look for the mark on the test print to determine which way the paper feeds through your printer.

steps.title: Press the printed photo onto a flat piece of wood.
steps.content: Press the printed photo onto a flat piece of wood. [17] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 9 September 2020. While the ink is still wet, lay the piece of paper on top of the wood. Use the side of your fist to press on the photo firmly. Rub it so the ink transfers onto the wood. [18] X Research source Work quickly after the photo is printed since the ink will only sit on the surface of the wax paper for about 5 minutes before it dries.

steps.title: Lift the paper gently off of the wood.
steps.content: Lift the paper gently off of the wood. Peel the paper off of the wood slowly so the picture doesn’t smear. The picture will look faint and the wood grain will be visible. Let the wood dry for 30 minutes before handling it. [19] X Research source
